Another opinion

There are many beliefs in God and the supernatural that seem to be constant over a wide range of religions. These are assumptions that are often so taken for granted that they are rarely ever considered. I would like to bring up a couple here for discussion to see what people think...
 
 1) Assumption: Belief in God necessarily includes a belief that God created Man and the Universe. Many earlier religions included gods that had no role in creation and I have heard that there are some minor religions that do not espouse supernatural creation stories. Why do we feel that, in order to properly believe in God, we need to believe the He created Man and the universe? How would it affect our view of God if we no longer believed in creation?
 
 2) Assumption: God is omnipotent, or at least powerful enough to be able to carry out anything which He wills. How would it change our view of God if God had limitations in that there were things which He wills, but cannot achieve? This is a question independent of the question of free will for people - since traditional belief in God says that He wants us to practice free will and, therefore, limits His actions by His own choice to let us make our own mistakes.
 
 So, what are your views in "thinking outside the box" about these assumptions we make about God?

The recent decades have revealed archeological finds of buried, decaying texts from those early times, as well as more efforts at independent scholarly research to find out about the origins of scripture based on archeology, comparative analysis, etc. These efforts in independent scholarship and archeology really only started around the 19th century and took off more in the 20th - relatively recent times. 
 
 Either way, if you take a look at Gnostic beliefs (where the Gnostics were one of the most prominent Christian beliefs in early Christianity, after proto-orthodox), then you will see how very different they are from our current belief systems in Christianity. Here is a link: Gnosticism - Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia (where you could also look at their section on Gnosticism and Christianity - i.e. the beliefs in Jesus held by the Gnostics). Gnostics believed that humans are divine souls trapped in a material world created by an imperfect god, the demiurge, associated with the God of Abraham (which is also the God of Christianity). Gnostic beliefs themselves varied widely. From that link:" Jesus of Nazareth is identified by some Gnostic sects as an embodiment of the supreme being who became incarnate to bring gnōsis to the earth. " Also, the fairly recently unearthed Gospel of Thomas was associated with the Gnostic version of Christianity. The bottom line is that this is one example of a Christian belief that once existed that was detroyed due to the politics of the Council of Nicaea and whose beliefs were very different than the range of beliefs that Christians currently hold.

 I think that one has to see that there are certain psychological needs that many religions, whether actually real or not, address better than does purely secular thought and that is why I would guess that religion of some sort will take a very long time to disappear and might indeed last indefinitely. Some of religion's answers to these psychological needs may indeed be a crutch but not a complete one. For example, one psychological advantage of religion is in letting people get a sense that God might be helping in directing their lives - something that gives them more confidence in a direction that they choose to pursue. However, just because they feel that God is helping to guide them doesn't mean that they don't recognize that they also need to be proactive - thus the expression "God helps those who help themselves". Also, another psychological advanatage of certain religious beliefs is a sense of cosmic justice attributed to those guilty parties that never suffer justice here on earth. That sense of cosmic justice is very sattisfying to those who have been wronged or exploited - which constitutes the great majority of the people of the world, to a larger or smaller extent. However, that doesn't mean that they themselves will not also try to pursue justice here on earth. 
 
 Both of these issues are issues that are hard for a purely secular world to fully address. However, there is another psychologically beneficial aspect of religion that the secular world could address but is doing a relatively poor job of doing. Namely, many people go to religion for a sense of community and support - especially those people who are facing grave problems in their lives. This has drawn many converts to religion - especially the more fundamentalist religions that reach out their hands to such people in trouble. The secular world could help stem that flow by being much more welcoming to such marginalized people.

 The unalienable rights is just another term for the philosophical idea of natural rights. Indeed, there were many who viewed natural rights in a religious light - i.e. that they came from God, but other philosophers had more secular approaches to the idea of natural rights. However, either way, the reason that natural (a.k.a. unalienable) rights were never included in the structure of our government (i.e. the US Constitution) but remained only a vague philosophical statement in the Declaration of Independence was that philosophers and theologians could never agree on exactly what these unalienable rights were. Certainly, the founders of this country did not agree on whether they should be applied to people of African descent. 
 
 From what I understand from summaries of the Federalist Papers, where the founders essentially illucidated their thinking process behind many directions taken by government, "All men are created equal" meant that all men should be viewed as equal under the law. This was in reaction to their experience with the British system where nobility were privilidged in not being as subjected to the rigorous justice system as were everyday people. Our current justice may be flawed in that those who can afford good lawyers are far more likely to get off, but at least technically the laws apply equally to everyone. That was not always the case.

One reason that Democrats support large government is that they view that government can be one of the few institutions that can have the power to try to at least slightly level that playing field so that, in the ideal case, the son of the homeless man might get the same opportunities for growth (through education, etc) as might the son of the bank CEO.  I am curious, why would you say that our government won't let people engage in business, buying and selling, etc. It makes no logical sense to me in reference to the US government. Even if you take the extremes of former Communist countries, my parents immigrated to the US from Communist Poland and I had a chance to visit there a few times as a teenager prior to its change-over to Capitalism. There certainly was a lot of buying and selling going on - mainly through people working in state-owned industry but there was a very lively private black-market of goods as well that was unofficially allowed by the government. The main disadvantage of the communist system was not that everyone was supported by the government - since very few were while the great majority worked. The main disadvantage (speaking economically) was that there was no incentive to work particularly hard since one gained nothing from hard work, so the economy remained very inefficient and, therefore, relatively poor.

 I do agree that we might mainly be talking about where one stands on the multi-part scale:
 --< more taxation/less taxation that supports...
 --< more government programs/fewer government programs
 --< don't fully trust industry so regulate / fully trust industry so don't regulate
 --< expect personal responsibility but balance that with government programs to catch people that fall through the cracks / expect personal responsibility but balance that with personal charity for those people that fall through the cracks
 
 However, to call current Democratic political goals Socialist (which, by the official definition that you linked, is full state ownership of industry) is to argue extremes, which is disingenuous and misleading and helps destroy communication between the two factions instead of promoting it. Neither party is at the extremes of this political spectrum - just the minority extremists that sometimes get the most press.
 
 I personally consider myself a left-of-center moderate in that I think that one needs to balance the needs of businesses, consumers and employees when thinking about labor laws and regulations controlling business practice. It should be obvious from the many failures of business to regulate itself (the latest financial crisis being one of many examples) that business cannot be trusted to fully limit itself - especially in a climate where the quest for short term gain overcomes any concerns about long term problems. As for personal responsibility, the great majority of Democrats are just as personally responsible as Republicans. Democrats, on average, do favor government programs to help alleviate the problems of the poor (to help give them opportunities to get out of poverty) where Republicans favor charity for the poor. Charity is all well and good and I do applaud the fact that Republicans do seem to give more in personal charity, but they often don't realize that charity isn't enough to overcome the social/economic obstacles of the poor. I last read that total US charity giving is about 350 billion dollars a year. That would not be enough to cover things such as support for the poor elderly (which is now covered by Social Security and Medicare), for the handicapped, etc. Charity, generous as it is, is simply not enough. What other option would there be - let the poor elderly die out or live homeless on the streets? It is compassion for the poor that drives Democrats to push for these social programs.
 
I've never been all that comfortable with a number of the programs you cite, but I think the fact that all but #'s 4 and 5 are basically in non-sustaining shambles is telling. (Note these are always topics that many, many people talk about as needing reform!) I don't consider #5 a socialistic matter necessarily, and #4 at least has some theoretical return in the long run.

 Many of these programs will become unsustaining since we are demanding more and more of them every year while being unwilling to pay for those increased benefits. In the past, with average lifespan being closer to seventy, then social security would have only needed to support the average elderly person for a bit over five years. Now it is closer to 15 years. Medicare also faces not only rising numbers of seniors (given the higher lifespans) but ever improving medical technology where access to that medical technology involves higher costs. What are the options? I would say that there are no good options. Either way, if we are to avoid sky-rocketing costs of health care in the future, health care will have to be rationed. It will not be pleasant but it is better than letting our country go broke in future debt. I propose biting the political bullet and reducing benefits to a point that is long-term sustainable while cutting un-necessary costs wherever one finds them and slightly raising social security / medicare taxes to make that bullet more palatable. What solution do you propose to this crisis? If you think that charity can cover the costs of care for the elderly, then you grossly underestimate how much is needed. Otherwise, do you think that we should, as a country, leave them out in the cold to fend for themselves - meaning many early deaths? It is easy to criticize - much harder to propose a real solution.
